content.text:
# War memorials in Surrey

The outdoor war memorials of Surrey, erected to mark the carnage of the Great War take many forms, the most common being a cross, either Latin or Celtic in design, mounted on a plinth which has suitable inscriptions listing the names of the local war dead. Generally, World War II casualties have been added to the original memorial though in a few cases, such as at Ashford and Guildford, there is a separate memorial. A few display a lantern instead of a cross. The other main group of memorials consists of plinth mounted statues of either allegorical figures or of soldiers.
Indoor memorials, such as those found in churches, generally consist of either metal or stone plaques inscribed with the names of the dead.
In addition to the conventional memorials, funds raised for memorials were often used to endow community facilities such as village halls or gardens of remembrance.
Outdoor memorials
{| class="wikitable sortable sticky-header"
!scope="col" class="unsortable"|Image
!scope="col" width=200px|Name and location
!Date
!scope="col" class="unsortable"|Description
!Listing
|-
|
|
----
Church Green, Abinger Common
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Edwin Lutyens and erected in 1920. The memorial is constructed in Portland stone. Destroyed by a V-1 flying bomb in 1945, it was rebuilt in 1949.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Alfold War Memorial
----
St Nicholas's Church, Alfold
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial is carved from Cornish granite and consists of a Celtic cross with a sword carved in relief on the shaft. A tablet with the named of those who died in the Second World War is beneath the plinth.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
|
----
Ash Hill Road, Ash
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Harold Falkner and erected on land donated by Isaac Field, whose son Ernest had been killed in the First World War.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Ashford War Memorial
----
Church Road and Fordbridge Road, Ashford
|style="text-align: center;"|
|Constructed in Portland stone, the memorial consists of a winged Victory on top of a plinth which commemorates the Old Scholars of the West London District School who died in the First World War. A second monument, comprising a tablet represented as an open book, records the casualties of World War II.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Ashtead War Memorial
----
St George's Church, Barnett Wood Lane, Ashtead
|  colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|Tall tapered Celtic cross on a square tapered plinth. The sides of the plinth have the names of the First World War casualties inscribed. At the base is a separate semi-raised marble tablet listing the World War II casualties.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Badshot Lea War Memorial
----
Badshot Lea Road, Badshot Lea
| style="text-align: center;"|
| The monument consists of two stone tablets mounted one above the other, the upper one for the Great War casualties and the lower one for those of World War II.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Men of Bagshot War Memorial
----
St Anne's Church, Bagshot
|  style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Frank Ernest Howard. Originally located at the junction of London Road and Church Road, it was moved to its present location in 1948.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Banstead War Memorial
----
Banstead High Street, Park Road and Sutton Lane, Banstead
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by George Jack, sculpture by Lawrence Turner, local residents.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Beacon Hill War Memorial
----
St Alban's Church, Beacon Hill
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Cecil Greenwood Hare in the form of a Calvary cross.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Betchworth War Memorial
----
St Michael's Church, Betchworth
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial was designed by Leonard Martin and is carved from Portland stone. It consists of a plain cross, mounted on a column that is supported by an octagonal plinth.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Bisley War Memorial
----
Guildford Road and Church Lane, Bisley
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Erected by the London Necropolis Company. Dedicated by the Bishop of Winchester
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Blackheath War Memorial
----
Blackheath, Wonersh
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial was designed by Charles Nicholson and is carved in Clipsham stone with a total height of .
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Blindley Heath War Memorial
----
Church of St John the Evangelist, Blindley Heath, Godstone
| style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial was relocated in 1989.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Bramley War Memorial
----
Horsham Road, Bramley
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial was designed by F.J. Hodgson and is carved in Portland stone with a total height of . It is set into a curved wall at the crossroads to the north of the parish church.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Bridley Manor War Memorial
----
Fox Corner, Worplesdon
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by the London Necropolis Company and erected in 1922. The memorial takes the form of a Celtic cross carved in Cornish granite. It was struck by a vehicle and toppled in 1954, but was re-erected. It was subject to further repairs in 1977 and a restoration in 1994.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Brockham War Memorial
----
Christ Church, Brockham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Charles W. Bowles, the memorial is carved from Clipsham stone. It consists of a latin cross on an octagonal column, supported by a octagonal plinth. The steps are made of York stone. The boss of the column has four faces, each with a carved shield. The memorial was blow down in a storm in 2004. Following a restoration project in the summer of 2009, the memorial was rededicated on 12 November 2009.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Buckland War Memorial
----
Village Green, Buckland
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Ebbutt and Sons, Croydon and constructed of Cornish granite. Dedicated by the Bishop of Sheffield, a former vicar of Dorking.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Burpham War Memorial
----
Churchyard of St Luke's, Burpham Lane, Burpham
| style="text-align: center;"|
| The monument consists of a tapered granite cross on a plinth bearing the names of the casualties. Dedicated by the Bishop of Guildford
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Busbridge War Memorial
----
Brighton Road, Busbridge
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Edwin Lutyens.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Byfleet War Memorial
----
High Road, Byfleet
| style="text-align: center;"|
|Predominately brick-built cenotaph with stone capping. The name panels are cast in bronze.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Camberley Memorial Cross
----
Haig Road, Camberley
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Unveiled by Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn, on land granted with a 999 year lease from the War Office.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Capel War Memorial
----
Church of St John the Baptist, Capel
|
| Celtic cross on plinth mounted shaft.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Caterham Hill War Memorial
----
St Lawrence Church, Church Road, Caterham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial takes the form of a Calvary figure in Portland stone. It was designed by Thomas Mewburn Crook.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Charlwood War Memorial
----
The Street, Charlwood
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Ebbutt and Sons, Croydon
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Chertsey War Memorial
----
Windsor Street, Chertsey, outside the parish church of St. Peter.
| style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial, designed by Joseph Whitehead and Sons, features a statue of a soldier raising his helmet in salute. It was dedicated by the Bishop of Guildford.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Chiddingfold War Memorial
----
St Mary’s Church, Chiddingfold
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Amongst the names of the men of the parish who died is that of Margaret Trevenen Arnold. Margaret was one of the first volunteer nurses to serve abroad, at a hospital in Le Treport. She died of pneumonia on 12 March 1916 and is buried in Le Treport Military Cemetery.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Chilworth War Memorial
----
Dorking Road, Chilworth
|
|Described by Historic England as "A simple yet dignified Latin cross memorial influenced by Blomfield’s Cross of Sacrifice".
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Chipstead War Memorial
----
Church Green, Star Lane, Hooley, near Chipstead.
| style="text-align: center;"|
|The memorial consists of a floriated cross, shaft mounted above a plinth.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Chobham War Memorial
----
High Street, Chobham and Cannon Crescent
| style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial was a gift from Miss Catherine Mary Percival, of Chobham House, who commissioned the London Necropolis Company to erect the monument. It is  high and carved from grey Forest of Dean stone.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Churt Memorial Column
----
Old Kiln Lane, Churt
|
| A brick and stone built column.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Claygate War Memorial
----
Church Road, Claygate
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial is carved from Portland stone and consists of a fleur-de-lys cross, around  high, mounted on an octagonal plinth. It is surrounded by a memorial garden and was restored in 2012.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Coldharbour War Memorial
----
Abinger Road Coldharbour
|
| The memorial consists of a tapered granite column with the names inscribed on each side.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Compton War Memorial
----
The Street, Compton
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Mary Watts who also supervised the construction. The memorial was dedicated by Rev A B Gwyn, the rector of Compton.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Cranleigh War Memorial
----
High Street Cranleigh
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Frederick Hodgson and constructed by  Thorpes, local builders. It was dedicated by Rev. Philip Cunningham.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Dorking War Memorial
----
South Street, Dorking
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Thomas Braddock
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Dormansland War Memorial
----
Dormans High Street, Dormansland
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Ebbutt and Sons, Croydon
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Dunsfold War Memorial
----
Dunsfold Common Road, Dunsfold
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by W. D. Caröe
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| East Clandon War Memorial
----
The Street, East Clandon
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Harry Stuart Goodhart-Rendel, the memorial is carved from Doulting stone and has a total height of . It consists of a cross on an octagonal shaft, supported by a plinth.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| East Horsley War Memorial
----
Church of St Martin of Tours, Ockham Road South, East Horsley
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial takes the form of a  cross, carved in Cornish granite.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Egham War Memorial
----
St John's Church, Egham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| A Latin cross mounted on an octagonal plinth  bearing the names of the dead.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Elstead War Memorial
----
Thursley Road, Elstead
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;" |
| The memorial takes the form of a granite Celtic cross standing on a Bargate stone plinth.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Epsom War Memorial
----
Ashley Road and Treadwell Road, Epsom
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Aston Webb, the memorial consists of a tall, rough-hewn, white granite Celtic cross. The names are inscribed in panels on a wall behind the cross. The cross was erected in 1921 but the name panels were not added until 1923. The gates at the entrance to the cemetery were erected to commemorate the members of the University and Public Schools Brigade which was hosted in Epsom.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Esher Memorial Cross
----
Esher Green, Lammas Lane, Esher
|colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|1920?
|Designed by Thomas Graham Jackson and carved in Portland stone, the memorial consists of a Latin cross on top of a tapering shaft mounted on an octagonal plinth. The Great War casualties are listed on bronze panels on alternate faces of the plinth, with World War II names on the intervening stone panels.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Ewhurst War Memorial
----
The Mount, Ewhurst
| style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial consists of a granite Celtic cross mounted on a tapered plinth. It was unveiled by Mr Walter Webb, whose son, Captain Evelyn Maxwell Webb, is listed on the memorial.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Farnham War Memorial
----
Gostrey Meadow, Farnham
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by W. C. Watson and unveiled by Lieutenant-General, the Earl of Cavan and Major-General Sir Walter Campbell.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Forest Green War Memorial
----
Forest Green Village Hall, Horsham Road, Forest Green
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;" |
|
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Frensham War Memorial
----
Frensham Road, Frensham
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Robert Morley, the memorial consists of an intricately carved Celtic cross mounted on a plinth.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Godalming War Memorial
----
Riverside park below St Peter & St Paul's church
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by A R Powys and dedicated by Rev. Fanshawe, vicar of Godalming. The Latin cross, mounted on a plinth, was positioned to be equally visible from both the churchyard and the park.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Godstone War Memorial
----
St Nicholas's Church, Godstone
|
|
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Grayswood War Memorial
----
Grayswood Road, Grayswood
| style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial consists of a Latin cross mounted on a plinth. On one face of the plinth there is a relief of a kneeling soldier looking up at Christ upon the Cross. On the front of the shaft is a niche containing an armour-clad figure.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Great Bookham War Memorial
----
St Nicolas's Church, Great Bookham
| style="text-align: center;"|
| A rare example of a cross with a carved figure of Christ on a war memorial.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Guildford War Memorial
----
Grounds of Guildford Castle
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Unveiled by Lieutenant General Sir Edmond Elles, Deputy Lieutenant of Surrey and dedicated by the Bishop of Winchester. The original monument was in the form of an arch with the names of the casualties inscribed on the supporting pillars. In 1995, a second monument, in the form of a plinth, was placed beneath the arch and inscribed with the names of the war dead from World War II.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
|  Guildford Post WW2 War Memorial
----
Grounds of Guildford Castle
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by David Annand, this is an unconventional memorial consisting of a bronze statue of a soldier holding a plaque bearing the names of men of the town killed in post-World War II conflicts.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Hale War Memorial
----
Upper Hale Road, Hale
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by William Curtis Green.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Haslemere War Memorial
----
High Street, Haslemere
| style="text-align: center;"|
|Designed by Inigo Triggs
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Horley War Memorial
----
Horley Recreation Ground, Brighton Road, Horley
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Ebbutt and Sons, Croydon.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Horsell War Memorial
----
High Street, Horsell
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Arthur Stratton, the memorial consists of a cross in Portland stone on an octagonal shaft, supported by a cruciform plinth. It is set in a paved semi-circular enclosure, surrounded by a low brick wall.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| King Edward's School War Memorial
----
King Edward's School, Witley
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial takes the form of a stone cross in Portland Stone on an octagonal shaft and was designed by Henry T. Edwards. The octagonal plinth is supported by a base of three octagonal steps.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Kingswood and Tadworth War Memorial
----
Brighton Road, Kingswood
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Frederick Bligh Bond
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Laleham War Memorial
----
Broadway and Shepperton Road, Laleham
| style="text-align: center;"|1920s
| An inscribed Latin cross mounted on a stone capped brick plinth.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Lightwater War Memorial
----
Guildford Road, Lightwater
|
| A wheel-head cross carved from Cornish granite
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Lingfield War Memorial
----
High Street, Lingfield
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Arthur Hayward, the memorial originally consisted of a gas lantern mounted on a shaft. The cross and lantern had been blown down by February 1945 and when re-erected, the gas lantern was replaced by an electric light.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Little Bookham War Memorial
----
All Saints' Church, Little Bookham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Cross carved from grey granite by Whitehead and Sons, Kensington
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Littleton War Memorial
----
Church of St Mary Magdalen, Littleton
|
|
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Long Ditton Memorial Cross
----
Ditton Hill, Long Ditton
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial is carved from Portand stone and consists of a wheelhead cross on an octagonal shaft, mounted on an octagonal plinth. It is at the centre of a memorial garden.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Lyne War Memorial
----
Holy Trinity Church, Lyne
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Carved in Portland stone by Farmer and Brindle
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Merrow War Memorial
----
St John's Church, Merrow
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Carved in sandstone, the memorial consists of a latin cross on an octagonal shaft. Each side of the square plinth has a relief carving of a rose.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Merstham War Memorial
----
London Road South, Merstham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial takes the form of a Celtic cross carved in granite.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Mickleham War Memorial
----
St Michael's Church, Mickleham
| style="text-align: center;"|
| A simple Celtic style cross mounted on a shaft rising from an inscribed plinth.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Milford War Memorial
----
Church of St John the Evangelist, Milford
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Molesey War Memorial
----
Hurst Road, East Molesey
|
|The memorial consists of a square tapered limestone column some  high.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Newdigate War Memorial
----
Church Lane, Newdigate
| style="text-align: center;"|1920
| Designed by J Hatchard Smith, the shaft-mounted cross has a carved wreath draped over it.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Ockham War Memorial
----
Ockham Lane, Ockham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Sidney Gambier-Parry, church architect and Ockham resident, the memorial is carved from Portland stone and consists of a Celtic cross with a tapering shaft supported by an octagonal plinth.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Old Oxted War Memorial
----
49 High Street, Old Oxted
|
|The memorial consists of a wooden board attached to the side of a house. In the centre is a carved crucifix. On each side there are two metal panels bearing the names of the Great War casualties.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Old Woking War Memorial
----
St Peter's Church, Old Woking
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Unveiled by: Admiral T P Walker, DSO. Dedicated by rev Norman Pares MA, Vicar of Horsell.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Ottershaw War Memorial
----
Christ Church, Ottershaw
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Dedicated by the Bishop of Guildford.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Outwood War Memorial
----
Church of St John the Baptist, Brickfield Road, Outwood
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial is in the form of a Celtic cross.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Oxshott War Memorial
----
Oxshott Heath, Oxshott
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|Designed by W. D. Caröe, the memorial was carved in Clipsham limestone. Originally  tall, the height was reduced after the memorial suffered damage in a storm. It is composed of a wheelhead cross on an octagonal column, resting on a square plinth. The base consists of five octagonal steps. The names of those who died in the Second World War are inscribed on the plinth, while those who died in the First World War are recorded on the steps.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Oxted War Memorial
----
Church Lane, Oxted
| style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial consists of a budded cross mounted on a hexagonal shaft rising from a square plinth.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Peaslake War Memorial
----
Peaslake Lane, Peaslake
| style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial is a simple cross mounted on a square plinth, described as "stylistically redolent of the period."
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Puttenham War Memorial
----
The Street, Puttenham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial is carved in sandstone and consists of a calvary cross on an octagonal shaft with an octagonal base.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Pyrford War Memorial
----
Church Hill, Pyrford
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Dedicated by the Bishop of Guildford.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Reigate War Memorial
----
Alma Road, Reigate
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Messrs J Underwood and Son of London. The memorial was dedicated by the Rev HG Hill.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Reigate and Redhill War Memorial
----
Shaw's Corner, Redhill
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Richard Reginald Goulden, the memorial was unveiled by Admiral of the Fleet, Earl Beatty.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Ripley War Memorial
----
High Street, Ripley
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by C.F.M. Cleverly, the memorial is carved from Doulting stone.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Rowledge War Memorial
----
Cherry Tree Road, Rowledge
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;" |
| The memorial was designed by H. Falkner.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
|
----
Frensham, Farnham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Harold Falkner in the form of a Celtic wheel cross, the memorial is carved in Penryn granite and is  high.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Seale War Memorial
----
Elstead Road, Seale
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial is  high and consists of a small cross on an octagonal column, set on a three-stage plinth.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Send War Memorial
----
Send Road, Send
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Unveiled by Colonel The Honourable A G Brodrick.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Shackleford and Peper Harow War Memorial
----
Shackleford Road, Shackleford
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by R.H. Butterworth, the memorial consists of a limestone cross on an octagonal shaft set on an octagonal plinth. The names of those who died in the Second World War were added in June 1950. Work on the memorial in 2004 included the replacement of the First World War names, which had been badly eroded. A further refurbishment in 2013 replaced worn York stone panels with new inscriptions in granite.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Shalford War Memorial
----
The Street, Shalford
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Dedicated by the Bishop of Guildford. Badly damaged in a road traffic accident in 2022 but subsequently restored.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Shamley Green War Memorial
----
Christ Church, Shamley Green
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial takes the form of a stone Greek cross mounted on an octagonal shaft. The four-sided plinth is supported by an octagonal base.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Shepperton War Memorial
----
Russell Road roundabout, Shepperton
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The  memorial is carved in Portland stone and takes the form of a cross mounted on an octagonal base. In 1987, the memorial was relocated around  to the south to facilitate the construction of a bypass road.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Shere War Memorial
----
The Square, Shere
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Spencer Munt, from Gomshall, the memorial is  high and was dedicated by the bishop of Winchester. The Maltese cross and plinth are carved from Bargate stone and the column is carved from Yorkshire grit stone.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Shottermill War Memorial
----
St Stephen's Church, Shottermill
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial is in the style of an in-filled lych gate with a crucifix above stone panels bearing the names of the dead of World War 1, the casualties of World War 2 are inscribed on the supporting pillars each side of the earlier panels.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| South Holmwood War Memorial
----
Horsham Road, South Holmwood
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Carved in Portland stone
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| South Merstham War Memorial
----
All Saints' Church, Merstham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The  memorial is carved in Cornish granite and consists of a tapering shaft topped by a wheel cross. The original Victorian church next to the memorial was destroyed by a bomb on 19 April 1941 and was rebuilt to a design by E.F. Starling in 1951.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Staines War Memorial
----
Market Square, Staines-upon-Thames
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Carved from Portland stone, the memorial takes the form of a winged figure of Victory holding a laurel wreath and a torch.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Stanwell War Memorial
----
High Street, Stanwell
|
| A baroque portland stone monument with an ornate plinth surmounted by a shaft with a ball on the end rather than the usual cross or lantern.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Stoke-next-Guildford War Memorial
----
Stoke Road, Guildford
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Original erected north of St John’s Church, it was moved to its current position in 1989. It was designed by E.L. Lunn and the  Celtic cross is carved from Cornish granite.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Sunbury War Memorial
----
Cedars Recreation Ground, Green Street, Stanwell
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Unveiled by Philip Pilditch, MP for Spelthorne, the memorial consists of a Portland stone cross on a York stone base. The plinth incorporates marble.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Thames Ditton War Memorial
----
Giggs Green, Thames Ditton
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by H.T. Edwards, the memorial is carved from Cornish granite. It consists of a  cross on which a bronze sword an laurel wreath are mounted. The names of those who died in the World Wars are inscribed on the octagonal plinth, which are supported by three steps.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Thorpe War Memorial
----
Mill Lane, Thorpe
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;" |
| The memorial takes the form of a Celtic carved from Cornish granite.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Thursley War Memorial
----
St Michael's Church, Highfield Lane, Thursley
|
| The memorial consists of a Celtic cross on a tapered square plinth, situated close to the west door of the church. WWI names are carved on east face and WWII names are carved on west face.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Tilford War Memorial
----
Church of All Saints, Tilford
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|early 1920s
| A Portland stone hooded calvary cross on a tapered column, set on a square stone base.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Valley End War Memorial
----
Valley End Road, Chobham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Charles Stanley Kimpton and erected in 1921. The memorial takes the form of a limestone wheel cross. A garden surrounding the memorial was added in 1922.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Virginia Water War Memorial
----
Station Parade, Virginia Water
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Walton-on-Thames War Memorial
----
Memorial Garden, High Street, Walton-on-Thames
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Unveiled by David Beatty, 1st Earl Beatty, the memorial consists of a stone wall, surmounted by the Royal Arms, with five bronze plaques recording the names of those who died in the First World War. The granite plinths in front of the memorial record the names of those who lost their lives in the Second World War and were erected in September 2002.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Walton on the Hill War Memorial
----
Breech Lane, Walton-on-the-Hill
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by L. Stanley Crosbie, the memorial is carved from Portland stone and is  high. It consists of a stone cross, supported by a square pedestal and three octagonal steps at the base.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
|
----
Warlingham Green, Warlingham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by J. E. Taylorsen, the memorial takes the form of a sculpture of a serviceman with a woman and child. In 1946, a rectangular tablet commemorating those who died in the Second World War was added to the base.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| West Byfleet War Memorial
----
St John's Church, Parvis Road, West Byfleet
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Reginald Blomfield, the memorial consists of a  cross on an octagonal base, both in Portland stone. Set into the cross is a bronze sword. The memorial was restored in the early 1990s, when the names of those who died in the Second World War were added. A rededication ceremony took place on 10 May 1992.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| West End War Memorial
----
Church Road, West End
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| The memorial takes the form of a Celtic wheel cross and stands  tall. It was originally erected at the junction of the High Street, but was moved to its current site in December 1972.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Weybridge War Memorial
----
Queens Road and Hanger Hill, Weybridge
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|Designed by J. Hatchard Smith and carved in Portland stone, the memorial takes the form of a statue of a soldier standing on a square column.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Windlesham War Memorial
----
Church of St John the Baptist, Windlesham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|The memorial is a granite wheel-head cross on a three-stepped York stone base.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Woking War Memorial
----
Jubilee Square, Woking
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Francis William Doyle Jones, the memorial consists of a bronze sculpture on a square sandstone column. Originally in Sparrow Park, it was relocated to Jubilee Square in 1975.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Woldingham War Memorial
----
Station Road, Woldingham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Liam O'Connor.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Wyke and Normandy War Memorial
----
Guildford Road, Normandy
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|The memorial consists of a Celtic cross on a plinth and stands on a plot of land leased from the War Office.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|}

|
| Ashtead Peace Memorial Hall
----
Woodfield Lane, Ashtead
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|1924
| Built to commemorate the end of the Great War it is owned and run by volunteer trustees.
| style="text-align: center;"|None
|-
|
| Leatherhead Garden of Rembrance
----
North Street, Leatherhead
| style="text-align: center;"|
|Unveiled by Major General Sir John Longley K.C.M.G, C.B., the memorial was dedicated by the vicar of Leatherhead.
| style="text-align: center;"|None
|-
|
| Sutherland Memorial Park
----
Clay Lane, Burpham
| style="text-align: center;"|
| Opened by the Duke of Edinburgh to commemorate the casualties of World War 2.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|None
|-
|
|
----
London Road, Camberley
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
| Designed by Frederick Walters as a memorial to Catholic military officers who had died in the First World War.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Windlesham Field of Remembrance
----
Kennel Lane, Windlesham
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|The first  of the Field of Remembrance were dedicated in 1950. The  Admiral's Field was added in 1987.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|None
|}

|
| Guildford railway station war memorial
----
Guildford Railway Station, Walnut Tree Close, Guildford
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|1922
| A white stone tablet with the names of the station staff killed in the Great War. In addition there is a memorial to the 262 dead of the Southern Railway in World War II.
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Holmbury St Mary War Memorial
----
Church of St Mary the Virgin, Holmbury St Mary
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
|-
|
| Royal Horicultural Society war memorial
----
The Old Laboratory Building, Wisley
| colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|3 June 1921
| Bronze plaque in a wooden frame commemorating the RHS students killed in the Great War. Unveiled by the President of the Royal Horticultural Society.
|  colspan=1 style="text-align: center;"|
